definition:
Natural deduction refers to related proof systems for several different
kinds of logic, intended to be similar to the way people actually
reason. Unlike many other proof systems, it has many rules and few
axioms. Sequents in natural deduction have only one formula on the right
side.

Typically the rules consist of one pair for each connective, one of
which allows the introduction of that symbol and the other its
elimination.

To give one example, the proof rules $\rightarrow I$ and $\rightarrow E$
are:

$$\frac{\Gamma,\alpha\Rightarrow\beta}{\Gamma\Rightarrow\alpha\rightarrow\beta}
(\rightarrow I)$$

and
$$\frac{\begin{array}{cc}\Gamma\Rightarrow\alpha\rightarrow\beta &\Sigma\Rightarrow\alpha\end{array}}{[\Gamma,\Sigma]\Rightarrow\beta}
(\rightarrow E)$$
